100.title: Registration and Breakfast
100.description: Please collect your badge at the main location: Hedwich-Dohm-Haus, Ziegelstraße 5, and enjoy breakfast that is also available at second location: Humboldt University, Unter den Linden 6.

101.title: Welcome words and Keynote
101.description: DevFest is the world's largest globally distributed developer conference and allows developers from all backgrounds to connect, learn, and exchange. In this keynote, Tim will set the stage for DevFest Berlin by providing background on the roots of the GDG program and Google's other developer programs, explaining the origins of DevFest, and exploring the social impact aspect of the broader tech ecosystem.

102.title: Into the hive of eBPF!
102.description: The buzz around eBPF is growing quickly and it is rising as an essential component for observability, security, tracing and networking within the cloud native ecosystem. In fact, it is changing the way we think about operating systems by opening the doors to fully customize the Linux kernel as a platform. In this session, we will cover the fundamentals of eBPF,its internals and core architecture. We will also delve into building real world examples and how developers can benefit from getting an inside look into their applications without code instrumentation, getting traces, analyzing the performance and identifying possibilities to improve using eBPF. We will also cover eBPF's benefits for cloud-native environments, highlighting its expanding landscape allowing to harness eBPF power and unlock its potential.

103.title: Exploring Data Analytics with Kotlin: From Data Ingestion to Deep Learning
103.description: Join us for an 80-minute workshop at DevFest that's perfect for Kotlin developers eager to explore data analytics. This hands-on session covers key aspects of data analytics and will empower you with practical skills. 1) Data Gathering: Learn how to collect data from diverse sources such as databases and files. 2) Schema Handling: Discover methods for automatically creating and designing data schemas. 3) Data Manipulation: Dive into Kotlin DataFrames to efficiently clean and transform data. 4) Data Visualization: Master techniques for visualizing data trends and insights effectively with Kandy. 5) Deep Learning Introduction: Get an introduction to using deep learning models for object detection in practical applications with KotlinDL. As an attendee, you can look forward to a highly interactive workshop. You won't be left to figure things out on your own. The workshop facilitator will provide simple skeletons, small tasks, and datasets. These practical resources will enable you to write just a few lines of code to complete various exercises and gain a solid understanding of the concepts being taught. It's a great opportunity to learn by doing and build your confidence in data analytics with Kotlin. Details for preparation is here https://bit.ly/devfest_kotlin_workshop

104.title: Mastering Go Testing and Benchmarks: Building Reliable and High-Performing Applications
104.description: Testing and benchmarking are crucial aspects of software development, and Go provides a robust framework for both. In this session, I will delve into the world of Go testing and benchmarks, exploring best practices, advanced techniques, and real-world examples. From writing comprehensive unit tests to measuring and optimizing code performance, attendees will gain valuable insights and practical knowledge to ensure their Go applications are reliable, maintainable, and lightning-fast.

105.title: Short break
105.description: Use this time to commute between 2 locations or get some coffee :)

106.title: Kill regression
106.description: In the fast-paced world of agile software development, efficiency and speed are key factors to success. Regression testing, while a powerful tool, may not always be the most practical solution in such environments. While this form of testing has traditionally been used to identify defects and issues with software, the process can be slow, expensive, and can impede development teams from experimenting with new code on production. For these reasons, many organizations have shifted their focus towards developing tools and environments that support testing on production. By leveraging tools like canary releases, shadowing traffic, and beta testing, developers can collect sufficient data points to ensure that a release is stable without the need for regression testing. These tools allow for more streamlined and efficient feedback on code changes, enabling engineers to experiment with new code and quickly identify and address any issues that may arise.

107.title: My journey from 'hello world' to developer advocacy
107.description: Have you in one time as a beginner, asked yourself or someone what path you should take to become, for instance, a frontend developer? I asked and got asked this question a lot but there is no one correct answer to this question. Personally, my tech career path to becoming a developing advocate has been anything but a straight path. My journey has been one of discovery, growth, and passion. From the excitement of writing my very first line of code, building developer communities to being a Developer Advocate at Adyen, my path has been marked by milestones that shaped me into who I am today. In this talk, I will share my journey from 'hello world' to developer advocacy.

109.title: How to teach AI to know your API
109.description: New GenAI is the powerful thing. And we at monday.com decide to take it to the next level by teaching LLM how to produce perfect valid GraphQL queries based on our API. During this talk I will share what technics we used to achieve it, how we used Google's Vertex AI suite and what we learned from this journey.

110.title: How I used Siri, PaLM, LangChain, and Firebase to create an Exobrain
110.description: In our fast paced world, there is just too much information, and it often seems impossible to keep up with everything that’s going on. If you ever felt that you couldn’t possibly remember everything you saw, read, or even didn’t read, come to this talk and I will show you how I build an app that allows me to do just that. I will show you how I used SwiftUI to build a beautiful app that works across Apple’s platforms, used Cloud Firestore to store gigabytes of data, keeping it in sync across all of my devices, used the PaLM API to summarise articles, and ask my app questions about articles, used LangChain to connect PaLM to my personal data store, Use Siri to provide a natural language interface that allows me to query my knowledge base hands-free

111.title: You might not need Cloud Dataflow, but you definitely need security.
111.description: In this talk, we'll explore alternatives to using Cloud Dataflow as the tool for building streaming pipelines, specifically looking at Cloud Run instead. But, using Cloud Run, there are security considerations to contend with, and we'll need to make sure it's secure.

112.title: TextField in Jetpack Compose: past, present and future
112.description: Text input is a fundamental text component used in practically all apps at some point, from simple usage in a login screen to complex dynamic server-driven forms. In this talk we’ll recap current text input APIs and their shortcomings, in particular for state management. As well we’ll explore the brand new BasicTextField2 API surface for common scenarios along with filtering, selection, gestures and more. The API you've been waiting for is coming to you soon :)

113.title: Happy Healthy Team
113.description: I have been working in web development for 13 years. I worked as a single developer, as a team member, team leader, and as a manager who is responsible for the success of the project. Quite often, Frontend work is the final step before the releases. How not to go crazy when you have just 2 weeks before the release, and the design is not yet fully ready? What to do if you have a new technology stack and the team has not already handled it? What if the important developers leave the team before the release? Let’s talk about how to build processes in a team to have a self-managing team with a healthy environment. At some point, each of us realizes that our job is not only moving Jira tickets. :)

114.title: New CSS transitions: Let´s smooth it
114.description: Let´s play around with what is new on CSS, this workshop cover exercises with scroll driven animations and smooth entry and exit animations. Before we are going to have an introduction over the new initiatives that are helping to move forward those new features, such as, Interop and Baseline. For the exercises we are going to build a landing page to test the Scroll driven animations and work with some new HTML tags popover and dialog for testing the new entry and exit capabilities on web UI.

115.title: web-platform-align: baseline
115.description: Look, there’s another feature shipped: cool demos, thorough articles, exciting! But is it ready for prime time? Let’s see… Half-baked in Nightly, behind the flag in Canary, kinda stable in Preview, and a bit buggy in Beta. And, of course, the spec is in the Working Draft. Meaning, what exactly? Nah, let’s wait… until you forget about it. The Baseline is here to save you from confusion and introduce stable snapshots to the Web Platform.

116.title: Gilded Rose Refactoring Kata
116.description: Gilded Rose code kata is an exercise designed to practice your refactoring skills. It simulates a legacy project in which you need to improve the code so you can add a new feature. In this live coding session, I will use the Kotlin version of the kata to show how a sequence of incremental improvements can make a difference, taking program design to a better and more functional place. You will see a few refactoring heuristics, IntelliJ tips and tricks, and design emerging from seemingly chaotic code.

117.title: Android Accessibility: Do or Do
117.description: It is more convenient for blind people to use a smartphone than a computer! Of course, this statement is not true for everyone, but there are more and more smartphone users, and mobile operating systems are very quickly developing an accessible environment. Creating an application and uploading it to the store is also becoming easier. But these apps are often inaccessible to users with disabilities and do not work properly with accessibility settings (such as larger fonts). I'll go through the main problems that users face and tell you how to solve them.

119.title: Closing Keynote
119.description: Join us at the main location: Hedwich-Dohm-Haus, Ziegelstraße 5, and get the chance to get cool swag, group picture, and networking!

0.title: Speed Up Microservice Setup with Composable Approach
0.description: Imagine how good it would be to have a magic button to set up and integrate a brand-new microservice in your ecosystem in XX minutes. Infrastructure, CI/CD, and basic code snippets all in one. This workshop aimed to familiarize you with the composable approach -- closest to the "magic button" as possible.  In this session, we'll walk you through how Terraform conjures infrastructure like magic, shared workflows streamline processes, and Maven archetypes simplify code generation. As the cherry on top -- live demo of the accelerator approach with Google cloud platfrom.

123.title: Why mock Firebase when you can just test it with Patrol!
123.description:
During the workshop, we will prepare the whole E2E testing scenario using Patrol. You will learn how you can use Patrol finders to supercharge your tests and how you can test native features with Patrol native automations. As an example, we will test our Patrol challenge app with Firebase native interactions.

Preparation instructions
We require attendees to have Flutter 3.16 (latest stable) installed and have Android support - that means you should be able to build Flutter app on Android and run it on the emulator (API 33) or their physical device.

124.title: Mastering Containerized Local Development and Integration Testing with Testcontainers for Go
124.description:
Are you ready to streamline your application development and testing processes while building robust Go applications? Join our workshop to unlock the potential of Testcontainers for Go and embark on a journey to build a talk rating microservice from the ground up.
In this session, we'll guide you through the creation of a feature-rich microservice for rating conference talks, using a variety of technologies such as databases, caches, event brokers and AWS lambdas. We will put the emphasis in two crucial aspects:
- Containerized Local Development: Learn how to harness the power of Testcontainers for Go to simplify your Go application development workflow.
- Effortless Integration Testing: Explore how Testcontainers for Go empowers you to write integration tests with ease. See how containerized development naturally translates into seamless integration testing, ensuring your microservice functions as expected in real-world scenarios.
By the end of this workshop, you will:
- Gain mastery in containerized local development, allowing you to confidently manage your application's infrastructure directly in your code.
- Acquire the skills to write integration tests effortlessly, providing the assurance that your microservice performs flawlessly in diverse environments.
Containerized local development and integration testing can become your greatest allies in building robust and reliable applications. With Testcontainers for Go, they are much easier to achieve.

Be ready for the workshop by following getting started instructions

125.title: Angular Renaissance: What's New in v17?
125.description: Welcome to Angular Renaissance! Angular 17, an upgrade to Google’s prominent TypeScript-based web development framework, is due this months with a few new features. This talk will uncover the innovations brought us by this release, including a new syntax for control flow, deferrable loading and Angular.dev playground.

126.title: OpinionGPT: Exploring the Impact of Biases on Large Language Models
126.description: Human biases inevitably get picked up by Large Language Models (LLMs). Consequently, a considerable amount of AI research is dedicated to bias mitigation. But what if we were to flip the objective and explicitly model various human biases? OpinionGPT explores this idea and lets users see how different types of biases in the training data affect the way LLMs respond to questions. This talk will detail the training process together with associated challenges behind OpinionGPT, as well as discuss general implications of training such a LLM.

tim.bio: In his current role, Tim leads the regional execution and program strategy targeting developers and startups for Google's Developer Relations Ecosystem team in Europe and Israel. His favorite technologies are Flutter and anything related to home automation. In 2016, Tim authored a book about web security and identity for O'Reilly. Before joining Google, he ran PayPal's Developer and Startup Relations team in EMEA and APAC.
tim.name: Tim Messerschmidt
tim.shortBio: In his current role, Tim leads the regional execution and program strategy targeting developers and startups for Google's Developer Relations Ecosystem team in Europe and Israel. His favorite technologies are Flutter and anything related to home automation. In 2016, Tim authored a book about web security and identity for O'Reilly. Before joining Google, he ran PayPal's Developer and Startup Relations team in EMEA and APAC.
tim.title: Head of Developer Ecosystems, Europe

katya.bio: Katya is a Program Manager at Google Developer Relations team. Currently she is leading the Google Developer Groups (aka GDG) and Women Techmakers Ambassadors programs across Europe.
katya.name: Katya Vinnichenko
katya.shortBio: Katya is a Program Manager at Google Developer Relations team. Currently she is leading the Google Developer Groups (aka GDG) and Women Techmakers Ambassadors programs across Europe.
katya.title: Program Manager

manuel.bio:
Manuel is an OSS Software Engineer at AtomicJar where he maintains "Testcontainers for Go". Since 2003, he has held various roles in different parts of the development process, starting in 2003 working for the regional public administration in Castilla-La Mancha (Spain) until 2007, then worked at more traditional consulting firms. In 2011, he transitioned to product-oriented and Open Source companies, where he has served as a support engineer, trainer, and Core Engineer at Liferay, as QA Tech lead at Liferay Cloud. Finally, before joining AtomicJar, from 2019 to 2022 he has been involved in Engineering Productivity at Elastic as part of the Observability product. In every job he tries to improve the quality of the software products and processes from the automation and testing point of view.
He has also founded and managed a couple of small web development and systems consulting companies. Additionally, he organises the Google Developers Group in Toledo, Spain (GDG Toledo), where they run monthly discussions about software in its various aspects, serving as a small community outside the bustling Madrid. Manuel has delivered talks at different national and international events too.
Manuel holds a BS in Computer Science (UNED Spain), and a master degree in Research in Software Engineering and Information Systems (UNED Spain). You can find him on Internet as /"mdelapenya" everywhere.
manuel.name: Manuel de la Peña
manuel.shortBio: Manuel is an OSS Software Engineer at AtomicJar where he maintains "Testcontainers for Go". He has also founded and managed a couple of small web development and systems consulting companies. Additionally, he organises the Google Developers Group in Toledo, Spain (GDG Toledo).
manuel.title: OSS Software Engineer

glafira.bio: In the early years, Glafira was inspired by an idea to change CSS and HTML for an online text RPG and she never stopped because that was the way! Now, she is a member of the MinskCSS/MinskJS program committee and one of the creators of the Minsk branch of the famous Accessibility Club.
glafira.name: Glafira Zhur
glafira.shortBio: In the early years, Glafira was inspired by an idea to change CSS and HTML for an online text RPG and she never stopped because that was the way! Now, she is a member of the MinskCSS/MinskJS program committee and one of the creators of the Minsk branch of the famous Accessibility Club.
glafira.title: Accessibility Team Lead at SpurIT, GDE for Web

dmytry.bio: Dmitry has been programming since DOS times. He spent the last 15 years or so in Java lands, most recently working with server-side Kotlin.
dmytry.name: Dmitry Kandalov
dmytry.shortBio: Dmitry has been programming since DOS times. He spent the last 15 years or so in Java lands, most recently working with server-side Kotlin.
dmytry.title: Software Developer

vadim.bio: Frontend developer in love with the Web, browsers, bicycles, and podcasting.
vadim.name: Vadim Makeev
vadim.shortBio: Frontend developer in love with the Web, browsers, bicycles, and podcasting.
vadim.title: He/him, MDN tech writer, Google Developer Expert, co-host of The F-Word podcast.

fellyph.bio: As a seasoned Front-End Engineer with over a decade of experience, I always seek new ways to enhance digital experiences. I love nothing more than sharing my knowledge with others, so I'm a passionate advocate for learning and community building. Over the years, I've been lucky to be involved with tech communities worldwide. There's nothing quite like the energy of conferences and the exchange of ideas that takes place there. Over the years, I have spoken in more than 20 countries around the globe, sharing my expertise on all things front-end: CSS, performance optimization, machine learning, Progressive Web Apps (PWAs), and SEO. In 2019, my contributions to the DEV community earned me the title of Google Developer Expert in web technologies.
fellyph.name: Fellyph Cintra
fellyph.shortBio: As a seasoned Front-End Engineer with over a decade of experience, I always seek new ways to enhance digital experiences. I love nothing more than sharing my knowledge with others, so I'm a passionate advocate for learning and community building.
fellyph.title: Web consultant and Google Developer Expert

alejandra.bio: Alejandra is an Android software engineer and TL at HubSpot. Formerly Android Developer Relations Engineer at Google for Jetpack Compose (2021-2023). She's worked for multiple apps in the past, gathering a tenure of ~10 years in the industry.
alejandra.name: Alejandra Stamato

vasilika.bio: Vasilika has been a Web Developer for over 13 years (Frontend mostly, but also Fullstack).She had experience working as a single web developer, as a member of big teams in FinTech, and as a Team Lead of a small team. She enjoyed working on web 3D projects, awesome animations, visualizations, and good infographics. She is a speaker & organizer of tech meetups and conferences. She helped many students at different schools with learning web development. She likes tech communities and modern technologies. Last 7 years, she has been living in Luxembourg and holding a Luxembourg JavaScript meetup.In 2023 She started to work as a Developer Relations Engineer at Kadena.
vasilika.name: Vasilika Klimova
vasilika.shortBio: Vasilika has been a Web Developer for over 13 years (Frontend mostly, but also Fullstack).She had experience working as a single web developer, as a member of big teams in FinTech, and as a Team Lead of a small team. She enjoyed working on web 3D projects, awesome animations, visualizations, and good infographics. She is a speaker & organizer of tech meetups and conferences. natalie.bio: Natalie Godec is a systems/DevOps/cloud/platform engineer passionate about building secure distributed systems using the most fitting tech. In the past few years she's grown a particular interest in data platforms and security, and has recently stepped into the wonderful world of cloud architecture and consulting. When not thinking about the next thing to build, she enjoys photography and discovering the diverse cultures of the world.

In the past few years she's grown a particular interest in data platforms and security, and has recently stepped into the wonderful world of cloud architecture and consulting. When not thinking about the next thing to build, she enjoys photography and discovering the diverse cultures of the world.

peter.bio: As a senior developer advocate on the Firebase team at Google, Peter Friese is dedicated to helping developers build amazing experiences and high-quality apps using Firebase on iOS, Android, and the web. With a passion for empowering developers and fostering innovation, Peter works tirelessly with the Firebase team to make his vision of 'cutting short the time to magic' a reality. Peter is also the author of the book Asynchronous Programming with SwiftUI and Combine: Functional Programming to Build UIs on Apple Platforms and host of the YouTube show Better Safe than Sorry, which explores best practices for building secure apps. He has written code in BASIC, C, ObjectPascal, Java, Kotlin, Xtext, JavaScript, TypeScript, Objective-C, and a number of home-grown DSLs - but his all-time favourite is Swift.
peter.name: Peter Friese
peter.shortBio: As a senior developer advocate on the Firebase team at Google, Peter Friese is dedicated to helping developers build amazing experiences and high-quality apps using Firebase on iOS, Android, and the web. With a passion for empowering developers and fostering innovation, Peter works tirelessly with the Firebase team to make his vision of 'cutting short the time to magic' a reality. Peter is also the author of the book Asynchronous Programming with SwiftUI and Combine: Functional Programming to Build UIs on Apple Platforms and host of the YouTube show Better Safe than Sorry, which explores best practices for building secure apps. He has written code in BASIC, C, ObjectPascal, Java, Kotlin, Xtext, JavaScript, TypeScript, Objective-C, and a number of home-grown DSLs - but his all-time favourite is Swift.
peter.title: Developer Advocate, Firebase

yonatan.bio: Yonatan Levin has over a decade of tech industry experience, excelling in turning startups into market successes. Currently leading the AI Team at monday.com, his focus is on incorporating GenAI to create innovative features. Before spearheading AI initiatives, Yonatan was a key player in multiple areas at monday.com. Not only did he contribute to optimizing the API in aspects like performance and scalability, but he also built the mobile team from scratch. Outside of his role at monday.com, Yonatan is the founder of 'Android Academy', the world’s largest community of Android aficionados. As a Google Developer Expert, he is a staple on the speaking circuit of renowned tech events like Droidcon and DevFest.
yonatan.name: Yonatan (Yoni) Levin

Not only did he contribute to optimizing the API in aspects like performance and scalability, but he also built the mobile team from scratch. Outside of his role at monday.com, Yonatan is the founder of 'Android Academy', the world’s largest community of Android aficionados. As a Google Developer Expert, he is a staple on the speaking circuit of renowned tech events like Droidcon and DevFest.
yonatan.title: Mobile Team Lead

ayodeji.bio: As a Developer Advocate with several years of community experience, he has built and managed developer communities for Google, WordPress, Codecademy, and Polygon. He is an experienced public speaker and content creator. He create contents to simplify complex technical concepts. He is a seasoned open source advocate and loves hosting conversation and discussing various topics around Open Source education and sustainability.

valentin.bio: Valentin is a quality software wizard, with over a decade of experience in the fast-paced world of extreme scrum and agile environments. He's a master of effective software quality assurance and testing, and he's always pushing the boundaries of what's possible. Today, Valentin is working on the cutting edge of consumer-focused software development, building high-quality mobile apps and backends that delight millions of users. But he's not content to rest on his laurels - his biggest challenge is helping his teams build, break, and recover ecosystems at lightning speed, all while keeping their focus firmly on the end user. It's a thrilling ride, but Valentin wouldn't have it any other way.
valentin.name: Valentin Ranshakov
valentin.shortBio: Valentin is a quality software wizard, with over a decade of experience in the fast-paced world of extreme scrum and agile environments. He's a master of effective software quality assurance and testing, and he's always pushing the boundaries of what's possible. It's a thrilling ride, but Valentin wouldn't have it any other way.

christian.bio: Introducing Christian Otieno, a software engineer whose heart beats to the rhythm of Go. With a passion for this enchanting programming language, Christian weaves elegant code symphonies, harnessing the power of Go's simplicity and concurrency. Join them on a transformative journey of discovery, where tranquillity meets innovation and the world of software engineering is forever changed. Get ready to be inspired as Christian unveils the magic of Go, one line of code at a time.

With a passion for this enchanting programming language, Christian weaves elegant code symphonies, harnessing the power of Go's simplicity and concurrency. Join them on a transformative journey of discovery, where tranquillity meets innovation and the world of software engineering is forever changed. aleksei.bio: Tempered in the crucible of Apache Hadoop and Apache Spark, the last few years, Alex is working on Machine Learning frameworks for JVM programming languages (Java, Scala, and Kotlin). In 2017 - 2020 he worked on a ML module for distributed in-memory database, Apache Ignite. 2020 was a year when Alexey created and released the new Deep Learning framework in Kotlin (Kotlin DL https://github.com/JetBrains/KotlinDL). Since 2022 Alexey is working on different ML projects written in Kotlin for Code Generation and Object Detection.

kateryna.bio: I'm Software Engineering Consultant at Valtech, Google Developer Student Club Menor, Google Woman Techmakers Ambassador, passionate Cloud and CI/CD Automation Enthusiast. I mostly work with E-commerce projects, developing composable solutions and contributing to libraries for company-wide use. I summarize my experience in my blog, where I also share leadership tips and tricks for novice GDSC leaders.

julia.bio: QA Engineer at LeanCode for over 3 years. QA team leader and Product Owner of open-source Patrol framework project. Goal-oriented, interested in Agile approach to software testing.

mateusz.bio: In mobile development for 7 years. Went through Xamarin, React Native, native mobile to Flutter. Now we are only focused on doing mobile in Flutter 💙. Managing Flutter at Scale in Credit Agricole project. Co-founder of Flutter Warsaw - one of the largest Flutter meetups in Europe.
mateusz.name: Mateusz Wojtczak
mateusz.shortBio: In mobile development for 7 years and now focused on Flutter. Co-founder of Flutter Warsaw.

daria.bio: Self-taught Front-end Developer currently working at Rabobank in the Netherlands. Women* in Tech Community Lead at Rabobank. If you don’t see her programming, she is probably sewing, roller skating or travelling around South America.

ansar.bio: I am PhD student at the Machine Learning Chair at the HU under the supervision of Prof. Alan Akbik. My main research interests are training LLMs in a data- and parameter-efficient manner, as well as LLM evaluation.

ansar.shortBio: I am PhD student at the Machine Learning Chair at the HU under the supervision of Prof. Alan Akbik. My main research interests are training LLMs in a data- and parameter-efficient manner, as well as LLM evaluation.
ansar.title: PhD Student in NLP @ HU Berlin

marco.bio: Marco is an Android engineer, currently working at TIER. He is a Google Developer Expert for Kotlin, he loves Kotlin and he has experience with native Android and native iOS development, as well as cross-platform development with Flutter and Kotlin Multiplatform. In his spare time, he writes and maintains open-source code, he shares his dev experience by writing on his blog, speaking at confs and organizing events with the Google Developer Group Venezia and he plays basketball.

marco.shortBio: Marco is an Android engineer, currently working at TIER. He is a Google Developer Expert for Kotlin, he loves Kotlin and he has experience with native Android and native iOS development, as well as cross-platform development with Flutter and Kotlin Multiplatform.
marco.title: Senior Android Engineer @ TIER
